Lacoste and 52 others<ref>https://launchpad.net/~launchpad</ref> | released = {{Start date and age|2005|06|15}} | latest release version = 3.0 | latest release date = {{Start date and age|2009|09|23}} | latest preview version = 3.1.10 | latest preview date = | programming language = [[Python (programming language)|Python]] | operating system = | platform = | size = | language = English | status = | genre = Project Management | license = [[Affero General Public License]] | website = <small>{{URL|https://launchpad.net/launchpad-project}}</small><!-- Size is intentionally reduced to maintain the integrity of the layout on some browsers. --> }} {{Infobox image |name = Mark-shuttleworth-launchpad-wiesbaden-big.jpg |size = 246px |caption = [[Mark Shuttleworth]] with other [[Canonical Ltd.]] employees. Discussing Launchpad at a design [[Sprint (software development)|sprint]] in Germany. }} '''Launchpad''' is a [[web application]] and [[website]] that allow users to develop and maintain software, particularly [[free software]]. Launchpad is developed and maintained by [[Canonical Ltd]].
On July 21, 2009 the [[source code]] was released publicly under the [[AGPL|GNU Affero General Public License]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ubuntu.com/news/canonical-open-sources-launchpad|title=Canonical releases source code for Launchpad|publisher=Canonical Ltd.|accessdate=2009-07-21}}</ref> {{As of|2011|7}}, the launchpad repository hosts more than 23,500 projects. The domain ''launchpad.net'' attracted 1 million visitors by August 2009 according to a [[Compete.com]] survey.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://siteanalytics.compete.com/launchpad.net?metric=uv|title=launchpad attracts 1m visitors yearly|publisher=Compete.com. |accessdate=2009-08-01 l}}</ref>
==Components== It has several parts: * '''Answers''': a community support site and knowledge base. * '''Blueprints''': a system for tracking [[Specification (technical standard)|Specification]]s and new features. * '''Bugs''': a [[Bug tracking system|bug tracker]] that allows bugs to be tracked in multiple contexts (e.g. in an Ubuntu package, as an upstream, or in remote bug trackers). * '''Code''': source code hosting using the [[Bazaar (software)|Bazaar]] version control system. * '''Translations''': a site for localising applications into different human languages.
A significant but less visible component is '''Soyuz''', "the distribution management portion of Launchpad." Launchpad is currently primarily used in the development of [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]], an [[operating system]]. Launchpad uses the [[FOSS]] ([[free software|free]]/[[open source software|open source]]) [[Zope 3]] application server.
==Collaboration tools== * [https://launchpad.net/trac-launchpad Trac/Launchpad Plugin] * [https://launchpad.net/bugzilla-launchpad The Bugzilla Launchpad Plugin] * [https://launchpad.net/drupal-launchpad Launchpad login module for Drupal] * [https://launchpad.net/drupal-teams Teams module for Drupal] * [https://launchpad.net/bzr-eclipse Bazaar Plugin for Eclipse] <ref>{{cite web |last= |first= |url=http://news.launchpad.net/api/launchpad-plugin-for-eclipse-using-the-launchpad-api |title=Launchpad plugin for Eclipse - using the Launchpad API |date=2008-11-14 |accessdate=2008-12-10 }}</ref> * [https://addons.mozilla.org/thunderbird/addon/9584 Bugmail] - for Thunderbird * [https://launchpad.net/leonov Leonov]
==Users== Several of Canonical Ltd.'s own projects use Launchpad for development including [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]] and Bazaar. Development of Launchpad is itself managed in Launchpad.
Other prominent projects using Launchpad for various aspects of managing their development include: * [[Drizzle (database server)|Drizzle]] * [[GNOME Do]] * [[Inkscape]] (bug tracking, code hosting)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.launchpad.net/general/inkscape-moving-to-launchpad |title=Inkscape moving to Launchpad! |date=2007-11-21 |accessdate=2008-09-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.inkscape.org/archive.php?lang=en&year=2009&month=12 |title=(Inkscape) Source code repository has moved to Launchpad |date=2009-12-09 |accessdate=2009-12-25}}</ref> * [[Linux Mint]] (bug tracking, blueprints, and translations)<ref>[http://www.linuxmint.com/blog/?p=970 Linuxmint.com]</ref><ref>[http://distrowatch.com/weekly.php?issue=20090727#news Distrowatch.com]</ref> * [[MySQL]] (code hosting)<ref>{{cite web |last=ArnÃ¶ |first=Kaj |url=http://blogs.mysql.com/kaj/2008/06/19/version-control-thanks-bitkeeper-welcome-bazaar/ |title=Version Control: Thanks, BitKeeper - Welcome, Bazaar |date=2008-06-19 |accessdate=2008-06-19 * [[OpenERP]] and [[OpenObject]] }}</ref> * [[Pinta (software)|Pinta]] (bug tracking and translations) * [[Upstart]] * [[Zope 3]] (bug tracking)<ref>{{cite pressrelease |author=Canonical Ltd. |title=Launchpad 1.0 Beta Released |url=http://www.ubuntu.com/news/LaunchpadRelease |date=2007-04-02 |accessdate=2008-06-20}}</ref>
==Transition to Free Software== Launchpad was initially criticized by the Jem Report and other members of the free software community for not being available under a free license, such as the [[GNU GPL]], despite its aims. In response, the developers stated that they aimed to eventually release it under a free software license, but that it could potentially take years.<ref name="developers-open-sourcing">{{ cite news |url=https://launchpad.net/faq |publisher=Canonical |title=Launchpad Frequently Asked Questions |date=2006-08-05 }}</ref> On 9 July 2007, [[Canonical Ltd.]] released "[https://storm.canonical.com Storm]", the first Launchpad component made available under a free software license.<ref name="storm-open-source">{{ cite web |url=http://www.ubuntu.com/news/storm-python-orm-open-sourced |title=Canonical Releases Storm as Open Source |date=2007-07-10 }}</ref>
Founder [[Mark Shuttleworth]]'s response to this criticism was that Launchpad needed paid-programmers to continue the development of the Launchpad platform, and that there would be no point in developing multiple versions of Launchpad due to the probable incompatibility of the [[Fork (software development)|forks]].<ref name="mark">{{ cite web |url=https://bugs.launchpad.net/launchpad/+bug/50699/comments/10 |title=Launchpad should be free software (free as in freedom) |date=2007-04-18 }}</ref> However, this still left some members of the open-source movement dissatisfied.<ref name="jem-report">{{ cite web |url=http://www.thejemreport.com/mambo/content/view/325 |title=Ubuntu is built with proprietary software |date=2007-07-10 }}</ref> On 22 July 2008 Mark Shuttleworth announced at [[O'Reilly Open Source Convention|OSCON]] that the complete source code would be released within the next twelve months.<ref name="open-source-announcement">{{ cite web |url=http://www.phoronix.com/scan.php?page=news_item&px=NjYwOA |title=Launchpad Source-Code Within 12 Months |date=2008-07-22 }}</ref>
On 19 December 2008, [[Canonical Ltd.]] released the Launchpad component "lazr.config" and "lazr.delegates" under version 3 of the [[GNU Lesser General Public License|GNU LGPL]].<ref>[http://pypi.python.org/pypi/lazr.delegates lazr.delegates 1.0]</ref><ref>[http://pypi.python.org/pypi/lazr.config lazr.config 1.0]</ref>
An open [[API]] is currently{{When|date=February 2011}} in beta testing, which will allow programs to interact with the website. Calls for an open API to be released were aided by projects like Leonov that resorted to [[Data scraping#Screen_scraping|screen scraping]] to get data from Launchpad.
In December 2008, Canonical announced that the source code to the Launchpad website would be released under a free software license by 21 July 2009.<ref>[http://uk.youtube.com/watch?v=oRa0fZTu-ms Youtube - UDS Jaunty - Graham Binns]</ref><ref name="opensourcing launchpad">[https://dev.launchpad.net/OpenSourcing Dev.launchpad.net], OpenSourcing</ref> It was also announced that two large components of Launchpad, Soyuz (which is responsible for the build system, package management and Ubuntu package publishing) and Codehosting, would not be released under a free software license.<ref name="blog-how">[http://blog.launchpad.net/general/how-we-are-open-sourcing-launchpad Blog.launchpad.net], "How we are open sourcing launchpad"</ref> Later, the specific date was changed to a more general timeframe of July/August 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://dev.launchpad.net/OpenSourcing|title=Open Sourcing Launchpad|publisher=Canonical Ltd.|accessdate=2009-07-04|quote=The process should be completed in July / August 2009.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ubuntu.com/news/canonical-open-sources-launchpad|title=Canonical releases source code for Launchpad|publisher=Canonical Ltd.|accessdate=2009-07-21|quote=Canonical, the founder of the Ubuntu project, announced today that it has open-sourced the code that runs Launchpad, the software development and collaboration platform used by tens of thousands of developers.}}</ref> However, on 21 July 2009, the software was released under the [[AGPL|AGPLv3]] (a fully free license specifically for web services),<ref>[https://dev.launchpad.net/LaunchpadLicense Launchpad License]</ref> including the two components (Codehosting and Soyuz) that were initially planned to remain proprietary.<ref>[http://blog.launchpad.net/general/launchpad-is-now-open-source Launchpad is now open source.]</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Free software}} * [[Comparison of open source software hosting facilities]]
